questions.question_text:
A security engineer has implemented an internal user access review tool so service teams can baseline user accounts and group memberships. The tool is functional and popular among its initial set of onboarded teams. However, the tool has not been built to cater to a broader set of internal teams yet. The engineer has sought feedback from internal stakeholders, and a list of summarized requirements is as follows:
✑ The tool needs to be responsive so service teams can query it, and then perform an automated response action.
✑ The tool needs to be resilient to outages so service teams can perform the user access review at any point in time and meet their own SLAs.
✑ The tool will become the system-of-record for approval, reapproval, and removal life cycles of group memberships and must allow for data retrieval after failure.
Which of the following need specific attention to meet the requirements listed above? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: The answer is BCE.
Given answer is correct
BCE. This one is a rare freebe.

comments.content: No way, this could not be more wrong. Responsiveness is always latency, and maintenance has nothing to do with this question.

discussion.content:
C, D , F 
check the link below:
https://www.mitre.org/publications/systems-engineering-guide/acquisition-systems-engineering/integrated-logistics-support/reliability-availability-and-maintainability

- Tool needs to be responsive: Latency
- Tool needs to be resilient: Availability
- Tool must allow for data retrieval after failure: Recoverability

comments.content: Why usability and not latency? According to the requirements "The tool needs to be responsive." The question asks: "Which of the following need specific attention to meet the requirements listed above?" Since the tool need to be responsive, then wouldn't latency require special attention?

discussion.content:
C. Availability
D. Usability
E. Recoverability

questions.question_text: A Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) has created a survey that will be distributed to managers of mission-critical functions across the organization. The survey requires the managers to determine how long their respective units can operate in the event of an extended IT outage before the organization suffers monetary losses from the outage. To which of the following is the survey question related? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: I disagree. B and E.

RTO - Disaster Recovery Plans
RPO - Business Continuity Plans

How long can a business operate after a critical failure (Disaster) before making loss - Recovery Time Objective. E is correct. 

B and D will also be correct. 

I say D because - Recovery Point objective is needed to calculate Business Continuity Plans which will also be needed in case of a disaster.
Should be D & E
lol given answer is right, look up definitions pls
It should be B and E

Selected Answer: C
We are collecting evidence to confirm whether there was a breach and RAM is most volatile (hence, the first thing that needs to be collected).

Selected Answer: C
You can find similar "order of volatility" questions in Sec+ and CySA+ too. 

As the analyst has determined not to remediate the damage as the first step, he would be going for the current memory contents.

comments.content:
The device "MAY HAVE been breached and accessed by an outside agent" and the security engineer is verifying whether or not there is evidence of this being true. So, we are trying to look at evidence and need to implement the order of volatility for collection.

I think if it had read as the PC being ACTIVELY breached in the present, then it could possibly be B.

discussion.content: B. keyword: outside agent

Agree C
The order of volatility is the sequence or order in which the digital evidence is collected. The order is maintained from highly volatile to less volatile data. Highly volatile data resides in the memory, cache, or CPU registers, and it will be lost as soon as the power to the computer is turned off.

Maybe: C. Dump the contents of the RAM?
The PC is not in the process of being breached. It is suspected of having been breached in the past. As such, checking ingoing and outgoing traffic won't tell you anything. You want to shut the system down ASAP because the system may be infecting other systems. But before you shut the system down, it is probably best to save RAM.

This is a tricky one.
A. Create an image of the hard drive -> Not what we normally do first.
B. Capture the incoming and outgoing network traffic -> If the system is on this is first.
C. Dump the contents of the RAM -> If the system is on this is second.
Unfortunately a very poor question, but I think I'd answer B on the exam.

comments.content:
I think you can check incoming and outgoing network traffic by viewing the logs, after the system has been shutdown. 
No need to keep a, possibly infected, system running for any longer than you have to. Dump the volatile memory, and shut the system down.

questions.question_text: A security engineer discovers a PC may have been breached and accessed by an outside agent. The engineer wants to find out how this breach occurred before remediating the damage. Which of the following should the security engineer do FIRST to begin this investigation?

choices.B: Capture the incoming and outgoing network traffic
choices.C: Dump the contents of the RAM
choices.D: Parse the PC logs for information on the attacker
choices.A: Create an image of the hard drive

choices.B: Constructing a known cipher text attack
choices.E: Using the application in a malware sandbox

discussion.content: Going with A on this one
A. seems a little heavy handed. I'd lean more towards D.

comments.content:
D. Performing a full packet capture 
Does not seem right to me. That is done when a packet is going from one point to another, usually to spy on what information is being transmitted. As far as we know, the app is running on the box in question. Besides, the issue is what is going on inside the application. 
I also have issues with A. Running an automated fuzzer 
Fuzzers usually spew out random data. That might make it difficult to "determine the input and output relationship." You would just get two sets of seemingly random data.
Oddly the pentester is not trying to break in, just to find the in/out relationship.
I think the best answer would be to input a series of carefully considered inputs, and try to find if there is a pattern between the input and output. But that option is not offered. 
Of the poor choices available, I think I will go with the fuzzer.
Heavy handed, how so? A seems correct to me.

questions.question_text: An internal penetration tester finds a legacy application that takes measurement input made in a text box and outputs a specific string of text related to industry requirements. There is no documentation about how this application works, and the source code has been lost. Which of the following would BEST allow the penetration tester to determine the input and output relationship?

A network service on a production system keeps crashing at random times. The systems administrator suspects a bug in the listener is causing the service to crash, resulting in a DoS. When the service crashes, a core dump is left in the /tmp directory. Which of the following tools can the systems administrator use to reproduce these symptoms?

discussion.content:
D seems correct.

https://www.microfocus.com/documentation/visual-cobol/VC232/EclWin/HHDGTHDEBG08.html

Maybe: C. Core dump analyzer? 
The question mentions the core dump, and specifies the location of the core dump. Since the network service is crashing at random times, there is no reason to think a fuzzer would tell you anything.

comments.content: On second thought. Since you are trying to "reproduce these symptoms" not analyze the cause of the problem in a more reasonable way, I would go with fuzzer.
You literally don't even do research before posting. There's no such thing as a core dump analyzer. If you search core dump analyzer you will see that a way to examine this is through a DEBUGGER.
And finding what caused the crash in the core dump will allow you to replicate it
